awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Development of an Antimicrobial Enzyme-Imbedded Bandage for Wound Care
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a material that may be activated by the wound and continuously produce a natural antimicrobial, hydrogen peroxide, until the clotting of the wound. Compared with existing products, this technology has an enhanced sterilization strength, does not use traditional antibiotics (no resistance concern), and could broadly kill pathogens. An example group of users is medical professionals or personnel that seek sterilization and protection to treat mild to moderate abrasions, cuts, and burns. Potential customers include physicians treating burns, skin surgeons, primary care doctors, and general populations. Besides wound applications, the technology may be adapted for other medical products for sterilization, e.g., incorporation into the membranes of face masks.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a material that may inhibit bacterial growth on the surface of the skin using the enzyme glucose oxidase (GOx). This technology may confirm the viability of GOx alone or in conjunction with other materials such as silver nanoparticles (AgNP) as an alternative to antibiotics in preventing bacterial growth on wounds. This proposed approach of preventing wound infections using GOx shows continued efficacy in acidic environments, and greatly improves growth reduction in gram-positive bacteria and gram-negative bacteria. Preliminary data shows a significant reduction in bacterial colony forming units (CFU) using GOx that has been fixed to a paper membrane. It is expected that the GOx paper membrane or GOx alone could be easily added to bandages or other materials to form antimicrobial wound care products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the feasibility of developing a commercial bandage using newly identified technology as developed in our laboritories at UA Little Rock. Our project used Glucose Oxidase enzyme to activate upon contact with blood and/or other bodily fluids, creating an antimicrobial environment in the bandage. Please see the image included with this report for more information and explaination. Our study indicated that this technolgy works as expected and a feasible new bandage product was developed at a comparable cost to existing products. The resulting bandage developed may have certain advantages in use, such as greater shelf life and additional healing capacity for some wound conditions. Further inveatigation imay be warranted into the actual degree of effectiveness for various bandage uses. The instrastructure does exist to support manufacture of this bandage product as well as the distribution capacity.

While this new product is already comparable to existing makers products, the already established commercial medical products manufacturers are fully invested in their own companies developed bandages and see little incentive to change their workable products for new and less proven designs. Therefore, we have no plans at this time, and under these market conditions, to take this forward as a business. Future conditions and needs may change this outlook. We will continue to monitor the field and any developments to allow bringing this bandage product forward commercially.


Last Modified: 03/07/2024
Modified by: Mitchell K Hudson

  • Image shows a figurative "band-aid" type bandage with the reaction that occurs upon exposure to blood or other bodily fluids for activation.
    Cordell Gilreath

    Mitchell K Hudson
    Proposed Bandage with Microbial Action
